channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Orders Officials to Stop Smoking in Public
item.description: Smoking is one of China’s most serious public health problems, and critics ask if the latest move to curb tobacco use will be any more effective than previous efforts.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: Delegates to a meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing break for cigarettes.

item.title: North Korean Leader Says He Wants Better Ties With South
item.description: In his New Year’s Day speech, Kim Jong-un called for improved ties with his country’s wary neighbor, while boasting of his regime’s tighter grip on power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Rodong Sinmun, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, rode a ski lift at the new Masik Pass resort, in a photo released Tuesday. Analysts said a primary goal was attracting Chinese tourists.

item.title: Old Rivalries Reignited a Fuse in South Sudan
item.description: The conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in a failure to achieve a lasting reconciliation between rival ethnic factions when the country was created in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: A displaced girl carrying water to a United Nations compound in South Sudan. Violence there has uprooted 180,000 people.

item.title: Kerry to Press for ‘Framework’ Accord to Keep Mideast Peace Effort Moving
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry hopes to secure a broad pact encapsulating basic agreements on core issues as a first step, but critics brand the move as an effort to play for time.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.S. Solar Panel Maker Seeks to Close Loophole in Duties on Chinese Products
item.description: Expanding a long-simmering dispute, SolarWorld Industries America has asked the Commerce Department to impose duties on solar modules containing parts made in China or Taiwan.
item.category: Yingli Green Energy Holding Company Ltd|YGE|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By DIANE CARDWELL
item.media:description: Workers pack solar panels in Baoding, China. The Commerce Department was asked to place duties on modules with Chinese parts, expanding a trade dispute.

item.title: Shelling of Bus in Northern Syria Caps a Merciless Year
item.description: The explosion in Aleppo killed at least 10 people, and more than 500 have died during two weeks of bombardment of civilian targets by the Syrian government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: The scene after a shell hit a city bus in Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Hamas Lawmakers Approve Large Budget Deficit
item.description: Hamas lawmakers on Tuesday approved a 2014 budget totaling $589 million for the Gaza Strip that included a staggering 75 percent deficit.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Cameroon: Kidnapped French Priest Is Released
item.description: Georges Vandenbeusch, 42, who was reported to have been held in Nigeria by Boko Haram, a group with ties to Al Qaeda, was released on Tuesday, according to French authorities.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: My Jewish State
item.description: Here is one prediction for 2014: This will be another year in which peace is not reached in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By ROGER COHEN

item.title: The Lede: On New Year’s Eve, Stuck in a Church in Bangui
item.description: The building has become a small island of refuge in the Central African Republic’s rapidly unraveling capital.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER MURPHY
item.media:description: Churches in Bangui have drawn thousands of Christians seeking refuge amid the conflict.

item.title: Egypt Says 3 Journalists Will Be Held 15 More Days
item.description: The journalists from Al Jazeera English face charges that include belonging to a terrorist group and harming Egypt’s reputation abroad.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and ASMAA AL ZOHAIRY

item.title: District Judge Upholds Government’s Right to Search Electronics at Border
item.description: Judge Edward R. Korman of the Eastern District of New York found that the government does not need reasonable suspicion to examine or confiscate a traveler’s electronic device.
item.dc:creator: By SUSAN STELLIN
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: Pascal Abidor sued the government after American border agents handcuffed him, placed him in a cell and questioned him for several hours, then seized and kept his laptop for 11 days.

item.title: The Lede: French Comic’s ‘Anti-System’ Salute Is Frequently Used to Mock Jewish Suffering
item.description: Until three days ago, the English-speaking world was largely unaware that the meaning of a French comedian’s stiff-armed salute, called a quenelle, is a source of heated debate in France.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sucre Journal: Headbanging in Bolivia to the Flutes of Yore
item.description: Heavy metal, Bolivian style, is a fusion of thrashing guitars and shrieking lyrics with the rhythms and instruments of pre-Incan Andean folk tunes.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fusion heavy metal band Armadura recording a music video in La Paz, Bolivia.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Ai Weiwei on Creating Art in a Cage
item.description: More than two and a half years after his release from jail, Ai Weiwei is still unable to leave China, his passport confiscated by the authorities. He talks about what that’s like and his plans for the future — if and when he can travel again.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei placed a bouquet in the basket of a bicycle as a protest against the prohibition on his travel abroad.

item.title: Afghans’ Plan to Release Prisoners Angers U.S.
item.description: Officials from both sides who support a security deal with the United States worry that a mass release of militants could bring a complete Western withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: A prisoner waited to leave the Bagram military prison during a release ceremony earlier this year.

item.title: Diplomat Back in Iran After Exile in the U.S.
item.description: Seyed Hossein Mousavian, a former nuclear negotiator, had been in unofficial exile as a Princeton scholar after he was accused of leaking secrets.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Left Without Mother, Girl Reflects on Typhoon
item.description: Jhoanna Awaaw, 11, lives in the ruins of her family’s seaside home in Tacloban, the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Putin, After Silence, Condemns Twin Bombings in Volgograd
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin called the attacks “inhumane terrorist acts” and vowed that Russia would fight terrorists until “their complete destruction.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolled the Battle of Stalingrad memorial on Tuesday in Volgograd, Russia. Over 5,000 extra troops are in the city.

item.title: The Lede: Assange’s Father Met Assad in Damascus
item.description: Julian Assange’s father met with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria during a visit to Damascus as a member of “a solidarity delegation” from Australia hoping to foster “peace and transparency.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: In Latvia, a New Year Also Rings In the Euro
item.description: The country became the 18th nation to adopt the currency, keeping alive the idea that despite its problems the euro club still has potential to grow.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: A Riga resident purchased a euro "starter pack" at a post office earlier this month.

item.title: The Lede: When Stranded in the Antarctic, Get Ready and Wait
item.description: Passengers on an expedition ship are preparing for evacuation after the weather clears.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Chinese Businessman Seeking Stake in Times Co.
item.description: Chen Guangbiao, who is known for public stunts, said he was leading a group of investors seeking to acquire a large or controlling stake in The New York Times Company.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Judge Orders Release of Dying Lawyer Convicted of Aiding Terrorism
item.description: Federal authorities had asked the judge to free Lynne F. Stewart, who was serving a 10-year sentence for helping her client, Sheikh Omar Abdel Rahman, contact his followers.
item.dc:creator: By BEN WEISER

item.title: Global Optimism for 2014, With an Eye on Dormant Risks
item.description: Although buoyed by a resurgence of stock markets in Japan and Europe, many investors were still wary, given the swiftness of the rebounds.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING, NEIL GOUGH and DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe attended a ceremony marking the end of trading for 2013 at the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
